clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Fatigue in Varying Hot Environments
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Fatigue in Varying Hot Environments

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York at Buffalo

clinical_study.source: State University of New York at Buffalo

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the impact of varying hot environments on physiological and perceptual fatigue during work.

detailed_description.textblock: After providing written informed consent and screening, subjects will complete two experimental visits during which they will complete treadmill work in either a hot/dry or warm/humid environment.

primary_outcome.description: The variable, jerk, determines smoothness or unevenness of physical movement during work. This is measured using accelerometers placed along the spine, ankle, and shoulder.
The amount of energy the body is expending during work. This is measured using indirect calorimetry.

secondary_outcome.description: The degree of fatigue that the subjects perceive during work. This is measured using a subjective likert 0-10 scale named the Fatigue Scale with 0 indicting "no fatigue at all" and 10 indicating "completely fatigued".

intervention.description: Work is completed in a hot/dry environment.
Work is completed in a warm/humid environment

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18-39 y old men and women
- Self-reported to be healthy
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of any cardiovascular, neurologic, renal, or metabolic disease
- Current tobacco use or regular use within the last 2 years
- Current musculoskeletal injury
- Taking medications with known thermoregulatory or cardiovascular effects (e.g., aspirin, acetaminophen, ibuprofen, beta blockers, diuretics, psychotropics, etc.)
- Currently pregnant or breastfeeding, or planning to become pregnant during the study
- Inability to follow the rules of the protocols or understand the consent form
- Contraindications of consuming a core temperature monitoring pill
